comments.raw_text:
Firefox 8.0, Nightly 10.0a1 (2011-11-08), Mac OS X 10.6.8

1. Open the Preferences.

What you see: A checkbox:

    [ ] Don’t load tabs until selected

When a checkbox label is negatively worded, such as starting with "Don't" or "Never", it's usually more confusing -- or at least takes longer to think about -- than if it is worded positively.

The usual fix is to reverse the meaning of the checkbox. Or if that isn't possible, to replace it with a pair of radio buttons.

In this case, radio buttons would be clearer:

    Restore each tab: (*) Immediately  ( ) When selected

comments.text:
It quickly becomes a mess to support wording for every detail.

By having the preference worded negatively, it allows us to better reflect the feature. When you check the box you are turning the feature on. On/off is better reflected by a checkbox than a set of radios.

I'm CCing somebody from our UX team to take a look and give some feedback.

comments.raw_text:
I had no problem understanding the negative statement.
I figured it implied exactly what it stated.
The check box is telling Firefox to not load tabs until they are selected. The only real change that should be made is to change from plural to singular "tab" not "tabs". Then the user knows that a given tab will not be loaded until it is selected by the user.

comments.text:
(In reply to Volker Glave from comment #4)
> Still I do opt for a different change (since we already went off-topic): In
> the current options dialog with the wording "Don't load tabs until selected"
> the actual apostrophe in the word "Don't" looks strange to me. That's not
> the usual kind of apostrophe ('), or is it? Looks more like (´), or so.

It's a typographic apostrophe, AKA "the right kind" - think smart quotes in Word & other programs. The straight quotes (single & double) on your keyboard actually have different meaning, but have fallen into more common practice because they're easy. But for a proper representation of English, they aren't correct to use in contractions or for quotes.
